title: Wait a second... the bard is a D*ck
body:
i was thinking about the video and something did flow to my mind: the bard did steal the cosmic egg from the ionian old man and send it to the sky.

when the bard appeared, the old man begged him to NOT steal it, since he said "without it we will die" and you know, they did probably died.

the bard did not help them, he was just wandering arround and beng a d*ck with ionians.

replies.body:
Bard is similar to Klaatu from the Day the Earth Stood Still.

He is not a friend to anyone specific on Runeterra; he is a friend to Runeterra and the things most precious on it.

It is not his job to save humans, yordles, etc. His job is to prevent the misuse of Runeterran relics.

He didn't intervene during the fall of Shurima or when the now Ruined King cause the isles to be consumed by the shadows of undeath. It wasn't a personal choice; it simply isn't part of his duty to solve problems created by the actions/inventions of the denizens.

He takes care of Runeterra and its' relics because they are unable to protect themselves. As far as Bard is concerned, everything else is secondary.
So he's like a museum curator who's so obsessed over artifacts that he's willing to let a village of innocents die because he goes full lawful stupid over artifacts.

In this example, the museum is full of artifacts that could take out the hemisphere they're located in, but were fortunately removed from the grasp of people who thought they were playing with firecrackers.

I'm not saying Bard gives out hugs on a regular basis (though they would be heavenly), but while he can be seen as being uncaring about a particular life, it's because he is busy protecting existence on a larger scale.

Even with that in mind, interpreting him as being a dick is, of course, a perfectly valid point of view.

I think the old man at least knew how powerful the artifact was (considering that he knew they'd all die without it). He didn't think he was playing with a toy, he was using it because he was fighting for his and his people's lives.

The thing that bothers me about him is not that he "cares" (ie. feels duty) towards a particular life, it's that he appears to have little to no compassion; he didn't give one @#$% about abandoning those people to die in order to secure the artifact. He didn't look down to show remorse, he didn't look back, he just twirled around whimsically and warped away. "This artifact was used; therefore it must be taken away" isn't really valid logic either, imo.

Personally I don't know if I'd even call him a "dick". I'm not even sure if I'd call him a "person", but if one could call a "thing" a dick then yes, I'd call him that.
The old man knew it was very powerful, but he had no idea how powerful it truly was.
Heartbreaker Bard, confirmed.
You are very good at your job. I read all of your posts in this thread and you made me look at bard in a different light. I now know what they pay you for.

and this is because i said the bard is a d*ck.

"is not part of his duty"
OF course, if it was part of his duty, the bard would just have been straight evil.
I don't think you can really call him a 'dick', in the same way you can't call an Elderitch Abomination (Lovecraftian) 'evil'. They're just in a scope that humans can't comprehend.

Yes,Bard took that egg away,but you have to keep in mind how powerful that weapon was.
If it wasn't for Bard,then it would have most certainly fallen into the hands of the noxians(since the old man was already down),just imagine what they could have done with something like that.

So yeah Bard probably could have saved the ionians here,but he still prevented an even greater catastrophe through his actions.

It's interesting to consider what would have happened if that last arrow had hit somewhere more vital. If the sage had not tapped into the object, would the commando squad of Noxians have delivered it back home? And would a less ... restrained wielder of the object have caused far more damage?

Remember the old man wasn't trying to level a mountain. What would someone of great power have done if they had been actually trying to?

Fun, fun.
Nothing, since Bard was going to take it whether it was belonging to an old man or not.
He took it because its power was unleashed.
oh, does that mean if the old man had let Noxus take it Bard would have waited for Noxus to use it before stealing it?

I imagine he feels the energy from the use of the artifact and thinks something like "oh boy, what are those kids playing with this time?  I had better take it away before they hurt somebody."
Only he thinks on a bigger scale, and so by "somebody" he means "everybody and/or everything."
So was this during the days of Boram Darkwill? Were Sion or Swain there or knew about that fight?

Fun fact: The big, particularly unpleasant fellow, who gets turned into Noxian ash in Mountain, wasn't Sion, but he was taking a similar role that Sion held before he became ... different. Noxian regiments aren't entirely, well, regimented, but there are recognizable roles within squads of a particular variety.

Arse-kicking, door smashing, line-breaking juggernauts being one of them.

Loping Cinder was particularly interested in that idea (among numerous other ideas) when he was working on the piece with the rest of the team.
So that guy was the Hand of Noxus? What other recognizable roles are there in Noxian military?

I'm not saying specifically the Hand of Noxus, as that's a more singular designation, I'm talking about the more generalized role in that kind of commando squad.

Due to work being done by teams at Riot, I can't go into the other details as of yet.
All I know is, he better not have been Darius and Draven's daddy. That was Sion before the retcon, and I'd rather not know the dad than find out he was replaced by Super Helmet-Bro.

I find this lore sort of disappointing because I had started to envision Bard as being really friendly and open, sort of like a cosmic {{champion:201}} with even better facial hair, who was just friends with everyone. Bard is hard enough to connect with with his lack of actual dialogue, so making him only caring about a larger scale makes him just completely impossible to empathize with

Having a blank slate champion is not necessarily bad. 

A lot of very successful characters are successful BECAUSE they don't have a defining characteristic or personality. It is a very old writing technique that TV tropes calls the Heroic Mime meant to increase immersion. Basically it means that since this character does not have a definite characteristic and have little to no dialogue or emotions that you can see. You (the audience) can project your personality on him and thus choose whichever emotion you want him to have and thus effectively become this character.  

AKA you are no longer a magician who is controlling an angry prehistoric rodent, you are playing as you. 


Some people argue that this is boring. They would rather pretend to be an axe-wielding powerful general who surfs on a wave of blood. Some will say that it's because they play games to ESCAPE their lives which sadly do not feature seas of blood but instead have waves of taxes. These guys have a perfectly valid point. 


But others like myself like the immersive experience. So I guess that in the end, it all comes down what kind of experience you are looking for. 


BTW i'm sure you'll want it so here's a list of Heroic Blank slate champions :)
Half Life 1/2 - Gordon Freeman
Portal - Chell
Legend of Zelda - Link 
Starcraft 1 - The original commanders who gave orders to Jim Raynor
THe witches by Roald Dahl - A book where a boy fights a whole coven of witches and we never realize until the end that he has no name 
And my username of course

You make a good point,
I would like to point out that all of those characters are human. The reason they can get away with not having personalities is because we already have that connection and we're already predisposed to connect wth them. 
However, the characters I see people complaining about being blank slates are {{champion:432}}, {{champion:150}} , {{champion:429}}  and {{champion:421}}. All of these characters are very weird, so there's already a gulf there in our connection. Therefore, riot would need to establish personalities for these characters in order to make them compelling. (I love Rek-sai, but it's all about the way she plays)

I can understand what you mean. These 4 are very weird and can be very hard to relate to but the fact that 3 of them are Non-verbal does not mean that they cannot communicate their emotions or have personalities that you can relate to. Have you seen the minions in Despicable Me? They all speak gibberish but they are still likable and have recognisable personalities even though they are practically indistinguishable. 

Gnar and Bard totally have personalities. It's just that Riot is experimenting around and trying to establish their story through the "Show, don't tell" technique. Bard in game is happy-go-lucky with his meeps, but when you see his video he seems very gloomy at the beginning when the humans are killing each other while he is playing his horn. I guess it's hard to be sure but that's the beauty of these characters. You can come up with your own interpretation. Oh and I love Gnar. Whether it's his bipolar personality or the fact that he is very playful, naive and enthusiastic compensates his lack of lines but what really sells it is when you have a big lane bullies like Darius picking on a tiny yordle but when he transforms they just shit their pants and go "HOLY SHIT, WHAT THE FUCK IS THIS!". 

Reksai is awesome but yeah you are right. It's hard to relate to her. Her whole kit is around primal savagery. It's hard to relate to that emotion. Kinda like Tryndamere who's always angry. You can feel it once or twice but you can't maintain it for long. 

I was suprised that you included Kalista on that list but you are totally right. She feels like an NPC. She has absolutely no motives except to fulfill the vengeance of her soulbound. She feels totally alien and yet she has a ton of interactions with other champions. She reads like an avatar of vengeance instead of a normal human who is bent on justice and vengeance. I guess that a bit of backstory to explain how she became like this or how she relates to other champions would help. It would certainly be useful if she could show a recognisable human emotion instead of just being cold. Even Rammus is more human and all he says is "Ok"

Oh well, like I said Blank slates are not necessarily bad. They can be very good if done right or alienating if they lack any feature. I guess it also depends on personal preferences.

I personally think that the lack of voices for some, while interesting and creative, is not a good story telling technique for creating an engaging character. It's very much a 'telling' rather than 'showing' way to tell lore. We are told of Rek'Sai's, Gnar's and Bard's lore and thoughts because they cannot vocalize it in ways we can clearly understand. To me a champion's own voice is one of the best forms of showing and not telling. Having a voice and personality that we and other champions can understand allows them to interact with us and each other. Without one they just kinda remain alone and don't add much to the world. Without the IoW to enable champion interactions, the need for champions to have means to communicate on their own is even greater I think.
     
The new lack of voices to me doesn't make sense from an in lore point of view either. As summoners we've always been able to understand champions and their words and thoughts (with a few exceptions like when Karma casts a spell or Yasuo ults). Champions from beyond RuneTerra like Malphite and Taric have never presented an issue before. The Void creatures never spoke completely in gibberish, so what makes Rek'Sai different? Godlike beings like Kayle, Morgana and Soraka never were too unknowable in their thoughts so why is Bard? Even the most mute champion (apart from Sona), Rammus, we can still understand more than Gnar. Skarner is incredibly ancient and 'alien', but he's very eloquent, so Gnar coming from the past isn't a good reason to speak in gibberish to me.
    
When Vi taunts Caitlyn, we can hear her own thoughts and what she thinks. When Graves smoke screens Nocturne (though it is a very bizarre interaction) we hear his snark for Nocturne. Sona never actually speaks a word, we just hear her through the Summoner/Champion connection. Other champions like Braum interact so much with fellow champions and even items that we get a very nice view into their mind and personality through their own words. 
    
Outside of game play champions can tell stories through their own words as well. The League judgments were wonderful examples of this, and the Journal (The interview with Shaco filled out so much of his character with his own words and actions). Quinn's journals helped build her and others as characters during the Freljord event, showing us much through words and pictures.
     
With champions that lack voices and such, the story telling becomes much more vague and 'meh' to me. Gnar's story is all told second hand. We learned more about Rengar than Gnar in his story. Gnar's personality so far to me is very one dimensional. He's childish and sounds very happy all the time. And...that's about it. Anything else is conjecture. I'd be much more interested in finding out his feelings towards other Yordles for example. Perhaps Heimerdinger could invent a device to translate for him if language is to be a barrier. Or we could have Gnar tell his own story through cave paintings (I'd love that as a Judgement). In game I'd enjoy hearing his voice and quotes change as he gets angrier and angrier ('Don't. Make. Me. ANGRY!', 'I feel...funny. Make it stop...'), akin to how Sion changes how and what he says depending on if he's in battle or not. When Gnar morphs new quotes and personality arise, and when he changes back he doesn't remember it at all (as far as I know). He doesn't have to give up his childish and happy go lucky demeanor, but something more than happy gibberish is something I think would make him a better character.
   
Bard's personality so far seems to be 'I work in mysterious ways. What I  do and why you can't even begin to grasp.' So...yeah. To me he's boring as a character though his kit is so much fun and his art and music are amazing. His voice, while neat, says nothing concrete and I have no idea what he thinks about anything. Again, Sona is mute and also very musical but we know her thoughts. His motivations are explained away as being about the big picture and so we have no way to get them. It's very jarring to me to go from champions that I can understand even if I don't agree with or like to a champion who is so alien that he makes Vel'Koz look normal. Experimenting with champions is fine, but I think this is a failure so far. There are many ways to write a character who is incredibly ancient or alien, has mysterious motivations (to varying degrees) and back story and with immense power, but still make them relatable or understandable at least. Doctor Who, Sandman, The Emperor and Chaos Gods, Sauron, Darkseid/Thanos, the Overmind, Merlin...all are less opaque than Bard but still with plenty to ponder I think. I don't mind mysterious, but I don't like 'You could never understand why.' It's just bad story telling to me, allowing any action to be excused with a hand wave. A character doesn't need to have every detail revealed up front, but neither should they have nothing. 

Rek'Sai is just boring to me as a character and without good reason not to speak. Her lore is entirely second hand even if it does expand the world a bit and have a decent video and diary. She has no interactions with other champions yet and I don't see how anyone really could with her being so primal and 'GRRRRRRRR.' She seems like even the other Void characters couldn't get along with her.
Well Tryndamere isn't always angry. He has a pretty good backstory and such as well. Not sure if his marriage to Ashe is still canon, but he does have an nemesis with Aatrox. Maybe some updated voice for him would be nice.

Rammus is weird in this regard, as he's so old (one of the original roster) and with so little back story that there really isn't much for him to say but we love him anyway. I'd like him to be fleshed (spiked?) out more without losing his famous 'Okay.' 

Just my personal preference of course.

Very insightful comment. I think these characters are super good additions because of variety; they can be used in different ways than other characters, and in different kinds of stories. 

The fact that you really must *try hard* to read Bard makes him interesting and capricious, even if he would have a hard time being the lead of a story in the usual sense. Gnar brings a toddlers childlike perspective, but is still a character that can hold his own. Kalista's lack of personality, I think, will make her moments of humanity *much *more impactful. She's the kind of character that starts out cold and hard as nails, but a pinch of backstory and a teaspoon of emotion and she feels nuanced and interesting.

Rek'Sai, while obviously not fit as a protagonist, serves the same role as the monsters in Jurassic Park, Jaws or Alien. Those are very beloved characters. They fill *most important* role in their stories. Rek'Sai can fill the role a generic monster couldn't; you know she is dangerous. You know she isn't disposable, because she's in the game! It's the difference between the Jurassic Park T-Rex and, say, the generic King Kong T-Rexes. I bet some players just like the joy of simply playing a *pure beast*, as well.

I guess the gist of what I'm saying is, every champion doesn't have to be able to play a protagonist or be relatable in the *usual *sense; they can also take other important roles. I think the variety will make the stories more interesting, if anything.

It depends on the game type. With something like Zelda or Portal it makes sense for the hero (us) to have little or no personality as they are usually pretty silent and their perspective is ours. 

Often times game makers will try to keep a character's personality and background vague so we can put ourselves in them more fully. It works with some (Corvo from Dishonored, the Doom Marine, Master Chief in the first Halo game), but with others it fails because they end up being 'not us' but just a very bland character (the guy from Watch Dogs comes to mind). Many first person games and such give their characters rich depth (Adam from Deus Ex:  Human Revolution) but with still some influence over their morals. 

With a game like League, each champion is not us though. They've always been their own entity with their own background and story and personality. We (back in the days of the IoW) as summoners merely bonded with them temporarily, never becoming them. I can't really say I am a murderous beast or king or warden.

Just because the boy in The Witches had no name didn't mean he had no personality. He wasn't a blank slate, just as Clint Eastwood's Man With No Name wasn't a blank slate.

I agree, in some games it works very well. Portal, Halo, Zelda as examples. Neo from the Matrix too. and sometimes it fails spectacularly because they no longer react like us. It's true League does not have singluar point of view protagonist. I was there too when we still had the institute of war and the summoners. But in the end, I felt that the existence of summoners itself became a barrier to enjoying champions. I mean look I enjoy playing Vi because she likes to charge into stuff. So much that I don't care if she's a girl. I like Braum because I can project my own desire to protect my team mates and lead the charge, I enjoy playing Amumu because his desire to have friends strikes a chord to me and even more so because he cannot stay in lane and must always roam the map all alone. In both cases, I completely ignored the main personality of these champions (butch lesbian XD, manliness and sadness) to project my own perspective on them, effectively turning them into my blank slates. That's what I mean by immersion. In real life, I don't care about lifting weights but when I play league it's ME who's leading the assault, not a mustachioed muscular mountain man who's blocking Draven's ult.

Of course, some people find it hard to connect with him what with his asian inspired influence and lack of voice lines. But in the end, I guess it all comes down to taste. I like Bard because he is so peaceful and playful with his meeps. I love that he is so free and can just imagine him saying WEEEEEE! when he takes a portal whereas Anivia who is a fucking bird cannot even soar. For me Bard does not say anything because he doesn't have anything to say that his bassoon voice cannot convey anyway. Personally, I think that Riot should have launched a Saxophone Bard skin with "Englishman in new york" playing in the background. But hey, that's just my opinion man. No need for a loser or a winner.
Not sure where the butch lesbian comes from but oh well.
Lol. I don't think she's a lesbian really but that's a joke that is circulating on the internet ever since she got her debonnair skin. It helps that she is brash and a tomboy.

Eh. I'm not fond of memes like that where stereotypes are used. Same with the Ezrael and Taric jokes and memes. Even if they are only meant in jest at first, they tend to become taken as true or encourage the stereotypes. Physical attributes don't indicate sexual preferences. I know you personally don't believe it, I just frown upon those sort of things.

To add to that and quote myself from another thread:

A concern of mine is that a few of the previous champions have been hard to relate to due to them being rather one dimensional and without voices of their own to tell their own stories. Kalista had her own voice(s), but was pretty much so focused on one thing, vengeance, that I couldn't really feel anything about her. Gnar is obviously childish, but he can't say anything for me to relate to. Rek'Sai is just a beast and even harder for me to identify with.

Bard has an similar issue to me. He's so 'complex' and above mortals, and lacking a voice as well that I can't connect with him either yet. More lore might fix this and I hope it does, but in the mean time I don't really feel much for him. It's fine to innovate in champion stories and how to tell them but not all innovations are equally compelling. A godlike being with reasons beyond my understanding is...meh to me as a character. It allows any action he takes to be explained with essentially 'He works in mysterious ways.' 'Why did he not save people in the village?' 'It's beyond your scope of understanding.'
If I may be permitted to make a comparison, myths with things like the Norse Gods and other pantheons are more interesting to me than stories about 'God' of the Abrahamic faiths. The reason is that the former are more relatable and lively with lots of things happening with them. They are knowable to us. The latter is rather staid and boring, lacking conflict and being too advanced for us to comprehend, so I don't even try.

well, i think rek'sai being a wild animal worked, at least for me, but I agree with you on the others. Hell, Azir has a similar problem to Kalista, only with SHURIMA instead of VENGANCE 
Like even the other void monsters have personalities, and they're supposed to be just as incomprehensible as bard
(that comparison does make me a little uncomfortable bc I'm Christian, but I can see where you're coming from: what I want in a narrative is pretty different from what I want in a faith, so yeah)

I didn't see a difference between her and any of the other void creatures so I didn't even understand why we couldn't understand her for that. But that's just my view.

Yeah I didn't mean anything with faith. Just comparing different powerful beings and how fun it is to read about them. As a story, deities and such with more human traits are more fun I think because they interact with humans and each other in ways we can connect with. Beings like 'God' and Bard so far don't really interact in ways we can connect with. They do things and we don't understand because 'Your mortal comprehension isn't advanced enough.'

also making bard incomprehensible is really lazy from a writing standpoint
"Oh, you want to know why Bard did this? Well, he's ~*~incomprehensible~*~"
"You don;t think what Bard did here made sense? Well, it made sense to him because he's ~*~incomprehensible~*~"
"You want to know how Bard would react in this situation? Well he could react any way, because he's ~*~incomprehensible~*~"
It's the epitome of lazy writing: Bard has no personality we can understand, so he has no characterization that needs to be kept consistent, so he can be written doing literally anything
http://archive.beefjack.com/files/2012/01/You-spoony-bard.jpg

Taken from the Q&A, a rioter agreed that this sums up Bards character.

>Looking deep into the character I get the feeling of a caring guardian, who's existence is too look after the ancient powers of this world (Maybe look after Nexuses? Nexi?). Yet I also get this contrasting, uncaring feeling, as if the mortal plane of existence is of no meaning to him except for the moments that history wants shaped. Did you design the deep personality of Bard to be this contrasting way? He is clearly no hero who saves mortals, yet looks after this world with a sort of delicacy.

The "caring" the rioter speaks of there seems to be more like a duty that Bard enjoys doing (especially since "history" deems what he must change, and he just follows), yet the rioter tries to make it sound like compassion. I don't care if Bard is some indifferent prick, but people should really stop painting him as "caring".

I wouldn't call the curator of a museum "caring" if he let a bunch of people die to save the displays in his museum.

A lot of things about him can cloud peoples judgment to his true nature. It did for more me at first.

His appearance doesn't inspire any feelings of fear or dread, he is a support, his title the care-taker, even his inspirations from studio gibli may cast a brighter light on him.

You have to remind yourself that he only cares about the world as a whole, whether you are in it or not is inconsequential to him unless he deems otherwise.
Don't get me wrong, I understand him, it doesn't mean I have to like him. On the contrary, beneath his cute exterior, I think he's creepy, obsessive, and -quite frankly- kind of sickening.
I see you undestand my point XD

For all we know, the old man was wrong and Bard's actions saved everyone off-screen and the village went on to throw a massive cake party, living happily ever after.
